#define UNDEFINED   { THROW( check_exception( "undefined operator" ) ); }

Detailed Description

Used for exception handling or simulation of exception handling, when older compilers are used.

The preprocessor functions and the class defined in this file were created at a time where exceptions were part of the C++ language only theoretically.
When using older compilers it is possible to simulate exception handling. The thrown exception is then written to the standard error stream and the program is interrupted.
For this simulation the flag HANDLE_EXCEPTIONS below must be set undefined.
Newer compilers now allow the full usage of exceptions, so when setting flag HANDLE_EXCEPTIONS below "defined", you will not receive an error, but the running program will exit without any specific error message. It is then your task to handle any exceptions by using the C++ try-catch-construct.

Define Documentation

#define HANDLE_EXCEPTIONS

If this flag is defined, all exceptions must be handled by the try-catch-concept of C++ (newer compilers).


If this flag is undefined, then throwing exceptions is simulated, by writing the exception type to the standard error stream.

Definition at line 102 of file ArrayCheck.h.

#define IO_CHECK ( cond   )     if( ! ( cond ) ) THROW( check_exception( "I/O error" ) );

Will throw an "I/O error" check exception when condition "cond" is violated.

Normally cond is a comparison like , so if then the exception is thrown.

Parameters:
cond the condition that must be fulfilled to prevent a check exception.
Returns:
none

#define THROW ( except   )     { throw except; }

Will throw a check exception of type "except".

If you use older C++ compilers without full support of exceptions and you have set the flag HANDLE_EXCEPTIONS, then program will be interrupted and the check exception type except will be written to the standard error stream.
If you use newer compilers with full exception support, then the exception except will be thrown directly and you have to handle it and extract its type by your own, using the try-catch-construct.

Parameters:
except type of the thrown check exception

M. Kreutz
Date:
